blocks.heading: Stop stagnating. **Ship faster on GitHub.**
blocks.description:
Move from Azure DevOps to the premium engineering platform.

Faster setup, built-in security, and CI/CD that scales without punishing your wallet.

blocks.heading: The cost of staying on Azure DevOps (ADO)
blocks.body: ADO is stable, but slow. Teams pay in roadmap lag, pipeline costs, and onboarding friction.

cards.heading: AI gap
cards.description: Repo/PR-aware Copilot lives natively on GitHub; IDE-only Copilot isn’t the same as org-contextual features on GitHub.com.

cards.heading: Parallelism tax
cards.description: Azure Pipelines licenses parallel jobs; new org free-grant is request-only and can take days.

cards.heading: Security add-ons
cards.description: Advanced secret/code/dependency scanning on ADO requires enabling GitHub Advanced Security for Azure DevOps (a separate, billable product).

cards.heading: Fixed-size hosted agents
cards.description: Microsoft-hosted agents can’t be scaled up; to get more CPU/RAM you must move to self-hosted/scale-set agents.

cards.heading: Roadmap opacity vs. GitHub
cards.description: ADO publishes a features timeline; GitHub maintains a detailed public roadmap board, making forward planning easier.

blocks.heading: White-glove migration, end to end
blocks.description: We plan it, run it, and stay until your team is confidently shipping on GitHub. No drama, no orphaned YAML.

features.heading: Pipeline translation you can trust
features.description: We rewrite Azure Pipelines into lean GitHub Actions, map secrets & environments, and prove it on a pilot repo with green builds and faster runtimes.

features.heading: Data moved, process intact
features.description: The importer handles repos/PR history and some policies; we migrate what it doesn’t (pipelines, work items, test plans, artifacts) and stand up Projects + reporting so rituals work day one.

features.heading: Copilot rollout & governance
features.description: We handle SSO, seat plans, guardrails, and training, so you get value without surprises.

blocks.heading: What you gain on GitHub
blocks.body: Faster loops, built-in protection, and an AI pair programmer that understands your codebase, with clear governance.

cards.heading: Copilot, but enterprise-grade
cards.description: PR-aware chat and summaries speed reviews; governed per-seat (Business/Enterprise)

cards.heading: Instant dev environments
cards.description: Codespaces + prebuilds cut setup from hours to minutes; budgets control compute/storage.

cards.heading: CI/CD at speed, security by default
cards.description: Actions bills on minutes, supports larger runners, and secret scanning + push protection blocks leaks (with partner actions/revocation).

cards.heading: Governance that scales
cards.description: Org-level rulesets enforce reviews/checks across repos; you can even manage settings “as code” via the Probot Settings app.

cards.heading: Automated dependency hygiene
cards.description: Dependabot raises fix PRs and scheduled version bumps; you can tune cadence and it pauses inactive repos automatically.

accordionItems.label: Do we lose history (PRs, comments, blame) in the move?
accordionItems.content: No. Repos, PRs, comments, and much of the metadata come across. Pipelines, boards, test plans, and artifacts need bespoke handling - we do that.

accordionItems.label: How much downtime should we expect?
accordionItems.content: Usually close to zero. We run pilots, parallel builds, and a low-traffic cutover with rollback ready. If something’s spicy, we pause, fix, and re-cut.

accordionItems.label: Do we have to rewrite every pipeline?
accordionItems.content: Not every one. We prioritize business-critical pipelines, translate them to Actions, and prove gains (faster runtimes, clearer logs). The rest follow a repeatable template.

accordionItems.label: What about approvals, gates, and variable libraries we rely on in ADO?
accordionItems.content: We map them to GitHub Environments, required reviewers, and OIDC + Key Vault integration. Same safety net, cleaner implementation.

accordionItems.label: How long does a migration take?
accordionItems.content: Common range: 3–8 weeks for a mid-sized org. We start with a 1–2 week pilot to de-risk pipelines and security, then scale.

accordionItems.label: Is Copilot safe for our IP?
accordionItems.content: With Business/Enterprise, you get policy controls, auditability, and org-scoped behavior. We configure guardrails and training so Copilot helps without leaking context.

blocks.heading: Tech wisdom from the trenches
blocks.body: At SSW, we’ve been knee-deep in projects for years: debugging giant solutions, fixing game-stopping bugs, and staying on the cutting edge. No guesswork, just proven tips that help you build better software.

cards.heading: What's New in GitHub Projects & Copilot
cards.description: Learn the latest GitHub Projects updates and how Copilot transforms your coding workflow. Includes live demos and real-world tips.

cards.heading: Switch from Azure DevOps to GitHub with Confidence
cards.description: Think GitHub can't replace Azure DevOps? Matt Wicks reveals the top 10 workarounds that make GitHub migrations smooth and successful.

cards.heading: Test Any AI Model in One Place. No Setup Required
cards.description: Skip the hassle of multiple API setups. See how to test OpenAI, Meta, and other AI models instantly using GitHub Models. Live demo included.

blocks.heading: Talk to us about your project today

buttons.buttonText: Start with a Free Migration Assessment
